content.description: Start with an obvious undercling flake. After the first clip, make the crux moves up to a big, crystalline jug, the "Tempura Flake". Easy sailing past 3 more clips will get you to the anchor.
content.location: This is the 2nd route right of the tree.

content.description:
Carefully scramble up ledges to a small overlap. The crux moves past the first bolt lead to interesting face climbing. Make a spooky ledge traverse to the right with the 2nd bolt below your feet. Two more bolts of

jugs lead to the anchor.
content.location: This is currently the 2nd bolt line fromÂ the left.

content.description:
The cruxes on this line are bolted, and it wouldn't be unreasonable to climb it on them alone if you're solid at the grade. However, for most folks, it might be best to bring a little gear. Another note: this short wall tends to stay mostly shady all day thanks to the tree cover.

Climb up and left around the low roof, passing 2 bolts, to a short left-facing corner (the right hand one). You can place gear here (either a finger size cam or ~ # 2 Camalot) or run it out a smidge to the 3rd bolt in the roof above. Crank the mellow roof on great holds, and climb past one more bolt (4th) and a perfect #0.75 Camalot placement to an anchor.
content.protection: 4 bolts and gear -- see the description.
content.location: There are 2 routes on an independent buttress, ~ 100' right of the main slab area. This is the right hand line of the two.

content.description: This route is fun and seems challenging for a 5.6. It seems like the hardest moves are near the bottom near the first and second bolts. There are great juggy holds up the rest of the climb. The crux seems a bit balancy with poor hands and good feet.
content.protection: 7 bolts and a two bolt anchor with lowering hooks.
content.location: This is the left of the two lines at the rock. The two climbs share the same anchor. The climb starts at a small, left-facing flake which provides a good layback hold at its top.

content.description: This is another fun easy route. Boulder up to the first bolt, and tackle a bulge after the 2nd clip. Head up a featured face to a fun overhang at the last bolt.
content.protection: 5 bolts and a 2 bolt anchor with hooks.
content.location: It is left of the tree.

content.description:
Step left onto flakes, then climb up steep(ish) rock to a ledge below the short, left-facing corner (the left of the two). Climb the techy corner/arete up and around the roof on cool holds to a short headwall above. Climb jugs up and slightly left to an anchor at the top of a short crack.

The rock at the bottom looks chossy but climbs better than it looks. The rock at the top is very good. Another note: this short wall tends to stay mostly shady all day thanks to the tree cover and would be a good spot after the other routes start getting hot.
content.location: There are 2 routes on an independent buttress, ~ 100' right of the main slab area. This is the left hand line of the two.

content.description:
This route flows well and is most difficult near the bottom. The first bolt is easy to clip before taking on the climb and any difficulties. The hardest part is over after you move above the second bolt. The climbing is not hard but makes you think before you commit to moves. It is slightly harder but flows easier than

Spider Roll

to the left.
content.protection: 5 bolts to a 2 bolt anchor with lowering hooks.
content.location:
This is the rightmost route at the crag and shares an anchor with

Spider Roll

, the route to the left. It starts atop a small, easy ramp from which the first bolt can be clipped.

content.description: This is the easiest route at the wall. It's a pretty fun jug haul. Follow 5 bolts up really featured rock to the anchor....
content.location: This starts right in the middle of the wall just right of a tree.

climbs.name: Crystal Lake Sashimi
climbs.fa: Mark Roth, Jay Eggleston, on Friday the 13th

content.description: This is the steepest route here. After clipping the high first bolt, things get interesting, and it doesn't let up until the anchor. Make a crux move left into the right-angling overhang after the 4th bolt. One last clip and a swing out left on amazing jugs will lead you to the anchor.
content.location: It is the first bolt line you see when coming up the trail.
